Et ego non obuiaui in eo unquam bono omnino, et non adeptus sum ex eo illud, quod sum adeptus nisi propter longitudinem lectionis librorum antiquorum, et studium super intellectum eorum, donec extraxi scientiam illius ex eis.	 And I have never encountered it in good form at all, nor have I attained that which I have attained except for the length of reading the ancient books and my devotion to their understanding until I extracted this knowledge from them.
Deinde adhaesi experimento et studio longitudine uitae meae.	 Then I adhered to experiment and study throughout the length of my life.
Et iam descripsi uobis ex illo in hoc Capitulo totum quod continet scientia mea: et super quod praeteriit experimentum meum, postquam abbreuiaui illud uobis, et liberaui illud ex occupatione elongationis, et abbreuiaui illud fine abbreuiationis, et ostendi illud fine declinationis: et formaui in eo formas multas ex formis instrumentorum quae administrantur in eo, cum sit ex additione declinationis, sicut feci in duobus Capitulis praecedentibus.	 And now I have described for you from that Chapter all that my knowledge contains: and over what experiment failed me after I explained it to you, and released it from the burden of length, and shortened it from the end of shortening, and showed it from the end of declining; and I formed in it many shapes of instruments which are administered therein, as I did in the two preceding Chapters.
¶ Summae, et collectiones ex esse fracturae ossium, ex eis quarum praemissio necessaria est, antequam incipiamus rememorationem membrorum fractorum, et diuersorum, si uniuscuiusque.	 Summary and collections from the existence of bone fractures, of which the premise is necessary before we begin to recall broken members, and of various ones, if any particular one.
Caput II.	 Title II.
Oportet, ut dicamus in prologo huius Capituli, summas sermonis, et capitula, ad quarum intellectum cogitur in primis artifex ad stationem super earum ueritatem: scilicet ut uos, et qui sunt prompti, sciant, uel addiscant hanc artem nobilem, et alii a uobis.	 It is necessary to say in the preface of this Chapter, the main points and chapters, which must first be understood by the artist at his station concerning their truth: namely that you, and those who are prompt, may know or learn this noble art from you, and others from you.
Dico, ergo, quod quando accidit alicui fractura, aut dislocatio, aut torsio, aut casus: tunc oportet, ut properes in primis ad phlebotomandum eum, et soluendum ipsum, aut utraque simul: si non prohibeat aliquid, sicut debilitas uirtutis: aut est ille cui accidit aliquid ex illis puer, aut senex decrepitus: aut est tempus uehementis caloris, aut uehementis frigoris ualde.	 Therefore I say that when fracture or dislocation or twisting or fall occurs in someone, then it is necessary to hasten firstly to phlebotomy him, and to be drained or both at the same time: unless something prohibits this, such as weakness of power; or he who suffers from one of these things is a boy or an old man worn out; or there is a time of intense heat or extreme cold.
Deinde sit contentus in cibo suo, oleribus frigidis, et carnibus auium, et haedorum: et prohibe uinum, et carnes grossas, et repleri ex cibis et omni cibo qui replet uenas sanguine.	 Then let him be content with his food, cold vegetables, and onions, and beans; and forbid wine, and thick meats, and filling himself with foods and all food that fills the veins with blood.
Donec quando securus sis ex apostemate calido, et non times effusionem materiei ad membrum: tunc redeat infirmus ad regimen suum primum cum quo cucurrit consuetudo eius.	 Until he is secure from a hot purge, and no longer fears the flow of matter to a member; then let the sick person return to his own diet first with which his custom was accustomed.
Cum ergo incipit os fractum restaurari, tunc oportet, ut cibetur infirmus cibis nutrientibus nutrimento multo, grosso, graui, in quibus sit uiscositas: sicut cibaria facta ex tritico cocto cum aqua, et rizum, et capita, et pedes, et uentres uaccarum, et oua, et pisces recentes: et uinum grossum, et similia illis.	 When the broken bone begins to be restored, then it is necessary that the sick person eat nourishing foods in abundance, coarse, heavy, with viscosity; such as food made from cooked flour and water, rice, heads, feet, entrails of cows, eggs, fresh fish, thick wine, and similar.
Cum hoc enim regimine fit coagulatio fracturae uelocius, et melius.	 When this regimen is followed, the setting of the fracture occurs more quickly and better.
Et scias, quod ossa fracta, quando sunt in uiris qui sunt in prima senectute, et decrepitis, non est possibile, ut continuentur et consolidentur secundum naturam suam semper, propter exiccationem membrorum eorum: et consolidantur et continuantur quae ex eis sunt in fine lenitatis, sicut ossa puerornm paruorum.	 And know that broken bones, when they are in men who are in the first old age and decrepit, it is not possible for them to be held together and consolidated according to their nature always, on account of the drying up of their limbs; and they consolidate and hold together those which are from them at the end of softness, like the bones of small children.
Verumtamen natura annectit super os fractum ex omni parte aliquid simile glutino, in quo est grossitudo, quo adhaeret et stringit ipsum, donec conglutinantur adinuicem, et ligantur adinuicem, donec uenit in fine fortitudinis et firmitudinis, sicut fuit in primis, donec non prohibet ipsum aliquid ab operationibus suis: et propter hanc caussam est necesse, ut ponas nutrimentum infirmi cibaria, in quibus sunt grauitas, et uiscositas, et grossitudo, sicut diximus.	 However, nature connects something similar to glue around the broken bone from all sides, in which there is thickness, by which it adheres and tightens it until they consolidate opposite each other, and are bound together until it comes to the end of strength and firmness, as it was at first, until it does not prohibit anything from its operations; and for this reason it is necessary that you place nourishment for the sick person in foods which have thickness, viscosity, and thickness, as we said.
Et scias, quod fracturae species sunt diuersae, secundum diuersitatem membrorum: quoniam fractura cruris, est diuersa a fractura ossis capitis: et fractura ossis pectoris, est diuersa a fractura ossis dorsi: et similiter reliqua membra omnia diuersa existunt adinuicem: et ego ueni cum rememoratione omnis speciei fracturae expositae in Capitulo suo distinctae ab alia.	 And know, that the types of fractures are diverse, according to the differences of the members: for a fracture of the leg is different from a fracture of the head bone; and a fracture of the breastbone is different from a fracture of the backbone; and similarly all other members exist differently to each other; and I come with the reminder of every type of fracture explained in its own chapter, distinct from one another.
Et diuersificantur species fracturae ossis etiam in seipsa.	 And fractures of bones are also diversified among themselves.
Quoniam fit fractura eius arcuata, praeter quod accidant in ea astellae.	 For there is a curved fracture (which occurs) besides the occurrence of stars (stellae).
Et quandoque fit fractura eius secundum longitudinem ossis: et sunt fracturae eius satagiae, id est, astellae, et additiones procedentes, sicut sunt in calamo, cum aptatur cultello ad scribendum.	 And sometimes there is a fracture along the length of the bone; and these are its cracks (stagiae, or stars), that is, splinters (astellae), as well as additions proceeding from them, such as in a reed, when a knife is sharpened for writing.
Et non procedentes: et est fractura cum uulnere et disruptione in capite: et est fractura fissura parua.	 And not proceeding (from the bone): and there is a fracture with wound and rupture in the head; and there is a small crack (fractura fissura parua).
Et omni speciei est ingenium, uel instrumentum proprium in restauratione eius, secundum quod ueniet rememoratio eius, distincta in locis suis.	 And every type has a skill or its own tool in its restoration, according to how it will be remembered, distinguished in its places.
Et ex eo quo cognoscitur fractura ossis, est tortuositas eius, et ipsius eminentia: et apparitio eius sensui, et sonitus eius quando comprimis ipsum manu tua.	 And from that which is recognized in a bone fracture, there is its twisting (tortuositas), and its protrusion (ipsius eminentia): and its appearance to the sense, and its sound when it is compressed with your hand.
Quando ergo non est in loco tortuositas apparens, neque sonitus apud tactum tuum cum tangis os cum agitatione, neque inuenit infirmus magnum dolorem: tunc non est illic fractura, imo possibile est, ut sit tortuositas, aut fissura parua: non ergo oportet, ut moueas ipsum cum manu et compressione omnino, imo pone super ipsum ex medicinis, quarum uenit rememoratio, post momentum illud quod conuenit loco: deinde stringatur strictura subtili.	 When therefore there is no apparent twisting, nor sound when it is touched with your hand or compressed with pressure, nor does a weak great pain occur: then there is not fracture in that place; indeed, it may be a twisting (or a small crack): thus, do not move it with your hand and compression at all; instead, lay medicines on top of it, which will be remembered afterwards, after the appropriate time has passed: then the wound will be sutured with a fine string.
Et scias, quod locus quando arcuatur, et scinditur in duo, praeter quod accidant in eo satagiae, uerumtamen remouetur omnis pars a compari sua: tunc oportet tibi, ut incipias ab hora tua ad rectificationem eius, aequando ipsum antequam accidat ei apostema calidum.	And know that when the place is curved and split, except for what happens in it as a result of strangulation, nevertheless, all its parts are separated from their own: then you should begin from your hour for its correction, equalizing it before hot ulcer occurs to it.
Si autem accidat ei apostema calidum, tunc dimitte ipsum diebus aliquot, donec quiescat apoestema.	 If a hot ulcer occurs to it, then let it be for some days until the ulcer subsides.
Deinde aequa ipsum secundum quemcunque modum potest ex lenitate et ingenio.	 Then equalize it according to whatever method can be done with gentleness and skill.
Et scias, quod restauratio eius, et ipsius aequatio, est facilior quam ossis, in quo accidunt satagiae.	 And know that the restoration of it, and its equalization, is easier than bones, where strangulations occur.
Deinde stringe ipsum, secundum quod ueniet tibi rememoratio eius.	 Then tighten it, according to whatever memory comes to you.
Si uero in osse sunt satagiae, tunc necessaria est extensio huius membri fracti ex duabus partibus, si manus sit, aut pes: aut cum manu tua, si membrum est paruum: aut cum duobus funibus, aut cum fune et manu.	 If there are strangulations in the bone, then necessary is the extension of this broken member from two parts, if it is a hand or foot: or with your hand, if the member is small: or with two ropes, or with a rope and your hand.
Et sit positio tua qua ponis membrum super locum aequalem, secundum figuram suam naturalem, donec quando extenduntur partes membri fracti: tunc conare, ut redire facias illas additiones omni ingenio, et secundum quemcunque modum potes in locis suis: et caue secundum fortitudinem tuam, ne accidat super infirmum per operationem tuam dolor, neque laesio: et conare secundum fortitudinem tuam, ut applices unum duorum ossium cum socio suo, secundum meliores formas.	 And let your position be when you place the member on a level place according to its natural shape, until the parts of the broken member are extended: then try, with all skill, and according to whatever method you can in their places, to bring back those additions; and be careful, according to your strength, that pain or injury does not occur to the weak due to your operation: and try, according to your strength, to apply one of two bones with its partner, according to the best forms.
Et oportet in illa hora, ut tentes et tangas ipsum manu tua.	 And it is necessary that at that hour you try and touch it with your hand.
Si ergo uides illic aliquid diuersum, rectifica ipsum, et aequa illud per quantitatem tuae uirtutis.	 If therefore you see something different there, correct it, and equalize it according to the measure of your strength.
Et caue extensionem uehementem, et compressionem fortem, sicut faciunt multi stolidorum.	 And be careful not to extend violently or compress too forcefully, as do many fools.
Multotiens enim faciunt accidere per operationem illam suam apostema calidum, aut contractionem in membro: sicut iam uidimus illud ex operationibus eorum multotiens.	 They often cause to occur by their operation a hot abscess or contraction in the limb; as we have already seen from their operations many times.
Deinde annecte post aequationem, et decentem operationem, et stricturam illius membri, et quietem, et tranquillitatem: et mone infirmum super ipsum.	 Then attach after the amputation, and a suitable operation, and the tightening of that limb, and calmness, and tranquility; and warn the sick person about it.
Et fac ipsum cauere, ne moueat ipsum in hora suarum uigiliarum, et somni sui apud reuolutionem suam, et agitationem suam, et apud egestionem suam, et omnes motus suos ultima uirtute sua.	 And make him be careful not to move himself in the hour of his watchings and sleep, at his turning and agitation, and during his illness, and all movements of himself with the utmost strength of his power.
Et ut caueat, ne sit positio membri positio cum qua sequatur dolor.	 And let him be careful that the position of the limb does not follow a pain.
Quod est, quia quando sentit in dispositione positionis membri dolorem, aut laesionem: tunc oportet, ut permutes ipsum ad dispositionem aliam ab illa cum qua non sentiat dolorem.	 Because when he feels pain or injury in the position of the limb, then it is necessary that he changes himself to another position from which he does not feel pain.
Et caue cum illo, ut sit positio eius illa aequalis, recta: ut non accidat in membro tortuositas, quando restauratur.	 And be careful with him so that his position is equal and straight; so that no twisting occurs in the limb when it is being restored.
Et qualitas stricturae membri fracti est, secundum quod narro.	 The quality of the tightening of the broken limb is as I have told.
Scias, quod membra fracta diuersificantur in paruitate sua, et eorum magnitudine, et ipsorum forma.	 Know that the broken limbs are diversified according to their smallness, and the size of them, and their shape.
Quae ergo ex eis sunt parua, sicut brachium, et digitus, et focile, et similia eis, tunc oportet, ut sit inuolutio panni mollis, subtilis.	 Those that are small, such as the arm, and finger, and foot, and similar ones; then it is necessary that there be a wrapping of soft and delicate cloth.
Quae autem ex eis sunt grossa, sicut coxa, et crus, oportet ut sit in eis inuolutio lata, dura.	 But those that are large, such as the hip and leg; it is necessary that there be a wrapping wide and hard in them.
Quoniam ligamentum latum, connectit membrum magnum, et stringit ipsum ab omni parte strictura aequali, ita quod non ingreditur ipsum macula.	 Because a wide bandage connects a large limb and tightens it uniformly from all sides with an equal tightening, so that no stain enters it.
Deinde incipe post euacuationem tuam ab aequatione ponere linimentum conueniens ad illud, in stuppa leni super locum fracturae ipsius.	 Then begin after your amputation to place a suitable ointment on it, on soft wool at the site of the fracture itself.
Deinde incipe inuoluere ligamentum super locum fracturae ipsius tribus inuolutionibus, aut quatuor, secundum quod meretur membrum: et stringe manum tuam parumper cum ligamento.	 Then begin to roll the ligament over the location of the fracture with three or four rolls, according as the limb deserves; and tighten your hand slightly with the ligament.
Deinde uade cum eo ad partem superiorem a loco fracturae, et stringe minus quam fuit strictura tua, qua strinxisti locum fractum.	 Then go with it to the upper part from the location of the fracture, and tighten it less than your previous binding that you bound the fractured place.
Deinde elonga te cum inuolutione a loco fracturae parumper, et mollifica stricturam paulatim, donec capias ex loco sano rem magnam.	 Then stretch the roll from the location of the fracture slightly, and soften the binding gradually until you take from a healthy place a large amount.
Deinde accipe uittam aliam, et inuolue eam iterum super locum fractum inuolutionibus.	 Then take another linen cloth, and roll it again over the fractured place with rolls.
Postea uade cum inuolutione ad partem inferiorem a fractura.	 Then go with the roll to the lower part from the fracture.
Et sit operatio tua in strictura inuolutionis, et mollificatione eius, secundum quod diximus in inuolutione prima superiore.	 And let your operation be in binding and softening of the roll, according to what we said in the upper roll.
Deinde pone inter inuolutiones ex stuppa leni, aut panno, cum quo aequetur tortuositas fracturae, si est in ea tortuositas: et si non, non ponas in ea aliquid.	 Then place between the rolls from soft wool or cloth equal to the curvature of the fracture if there is any curvature; and if not, do not put anything there.
Deinde inuolue super ipsam uittam aliam.	 Then roll over another linen cloth.
Postea aequa super has inuolutiones astellas decenter factas statim, si non est in loco inflatio, neque apostema calidum.	 Then place stars evenly over these rolls immediately, if there is no swelling or hot abscess.
Si autem in ea est inflatio, aut apostema: tunc pone super eam quod sedet illud apostema, et auferat inflationem: et dimitte eam aliquot diebus.	 If there is swelling or an abscess, then place over it what sits under the abscess, and remove the swelling; and leave it for some days.
Deinde stringe super ipsam tunc astellas.	 Then bind over them the stars.
Et sint Astellae ex medietatibus cannae latae, rasae, formatae sapienter: aut sint ex ligno unde fiunt cribra, quae fiunt ex pino, aut geraid, id est, ramis palmae, aut calingi: et sit amplitudo omnis Astellae, secundum hanc formam, et hanc eandem figuram.	 The stars should be made from the middle of a wide reed, shaved and well-formed; or they may be made of wood from which cribra are made, such as pine, elder, or palm branches, or calingi; and let the width of all the stars be according to this form and the same figure.
Verumtamen oportet, ut Astella quae ponitur super ipsam tracturam, sit grossior et latior parumper, quam reliquae Astellae: et longitudo Astellae sit secundum quod licet membro ex magnitudine et paruitate.	 However, the star that is placed over the affected limb should be a little thicker and wider than the other stars; and the length of the star should be according to what is appropriate for the member in size and thickness.
Deinde stringe super Astellas cum uitta alia, secundum stricturam primam eandem.	 Then bind over the Star with another plaster, according to the first binding.
Deinde liga desuper cum filis decenter, secundum quod diximus de strictura: et est, ut sit strictura tua super locum fracturae plus: et quanto plus elongatur a fractura sit, strictura minor.	 Then bind properly with threads, as we said regarding binding; and this is so that your binding over the site of the fracture is stronger than the fracture itself; and the farther away from the fracture the binding is, the less it should be.
Et oportet, ut sint fila media in grossitudine et subtilitate, et sint ex lino molli.	 The threads should be of medium thickness and fineness, and made of soft linen.
Quoniam si fila sunt grossa, sicut uidi ex operatione stolidorum ponentium fila sua ex chordis lini tortis, est error magnus: quoniam cadit strictura cum eis extra qualitatem.	 Because if the threads are thick, as I have seen in the operation of fools binding with thick cords of twisted linen, there is a great error; for the binding falls away from them due to their poor quality.
Et fila subtilia iterum non conueniunt: quoniam tu non consequeris per stricturam cum eis illud quod uis.	 And thin threads do not fit again; because you will not obtain with the binding what you wish.
Et non oportet, ut sit inter astellam et astellam minus quam digitus.	 It is not appropriate that there be less than a finger's width between one star (stitch) and another.
Quod si laeditur infirmus per extremitates astellarum post stricturam in locis sanis: tunc pone sub eis ex stuppa leni, aut lana carminata, donec nihil laedatur ex illo.	 If the patient is injured by the extremities of the stitches after binding in healthy places: then place beneath them with soft wool or camel's hair until nothing is injured from it.
Quando autem est fractura cum uulnere, et accidit disruptio in cute, ego ueniam cum rememoratione eius in capitulo secundum singularitatem.	 But when there is a fracture with a wound, and the break occurs in the skin, I will come back with regard to this matter in Chapter 2, specifically.
Et scias, quod non omne membrum fractum oportet ut stringatur cum astellis a primo die.	 And know that not every fractured member should be bound with stitches from the first day.
Quod est, quia membrum quando est magnum, non oportet ut ponas superipsum astellas, nisi post quinque dies, aut septem, aut plus, secundum securitatem tuam ab euentu apostematis calidi.	 Because when a member is large, it is not necessary to place stitches on top of it unless five days, or seven, or more have passed, according to your safety from the risk of hot abscess.
Et iste est modus emplastrorum, quibus restaurabant antiqui, quae ponuntur super fracturam et dislocationem.	 This is the method of plasters, with which the ancients restored fractures and dislocations.
¶ Modus Emplastri communis abbreuiati, restaurans fracturam, conueniens pluribus complexionibus, praecipue mulieribus, et pueris: quoniam est ex eo super quod non uincit calor, neque frigus.	 § Common Plaster Method summarized, restoring a fracture, suitable for multiple temperaments, particularly women and children; because it is from that which heat does not prevail, nor cold.
Et est, ut accipias ex puluere molendini, et est medulla farinae quae pendet in parietibus molendini apud motum molae: et conficias ipsum sicut est, praeter quod cribelles ipsum cum albugine oui: et pone confectionem eius non spissam, neque subtilem.	And it is to receive from the flour mill dust, and it is the kernel of wheat that hangs on the walls of the mill during the movement of the millstone; and make it thus, except that you sieve it with egg white; and place its mixture not thick, nor thin.
Deinde utere eo.	 Then use (it).
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, restaurantis fracturam, et dislocationem, et torsionem.	 Another emplastrum method, for healing a fracture, and dislocation, and twisting.
Recipe almess, et laudani, et acaciae, et enulae, et mugath: et suc, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V et alethil ʒ XX terantur omnia, et cribellentur, et misceantur cum aqua alethil: aut cum albugine oui, si complexio infirmi est calefacta.	 Prepare almess, laudanum, acacia, enula, and mugath; squeeze, from all of them an equal amount of juice, 10 parts of myrrh, 5 parts of each aloes, and 20 parts of alethil should be ground and sieved, and mixed with water alethil, or with egg white if the covering is heated for the weak.
Deinde utere hoc emplastro.	 Then use this emplastrum.
Nam ipsum est bonae compositionis, restaurat ossa fracta uelociter, et confert pluribus hominibus.	 For it is a good mixture, it heals broken bones quickly, and benefits many people.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius, quod etiam confert fracturae et torsioni.	 Another emplastrum method, which also helps with fractures and twisting.
Recipe mugath, et mess, et alteae albae, omnium ana ʒ X myrrhae, et aloes amborum ana ʒ V acaciae ʒ VI boli armeni ʒ XX terantur omnia contritione multa, et cribellentur, et conficiantur cum aqua, aut albugine oui: et administrentur.	 Prepare mugath, mess, white alteae, all in an equal amount of 10 parts of myrrh, 5 parts each of both aloes, 6 parts of acacia, and 20 parts of Armenian pounded bulbs should be ground with much pressure, sieved, and mixed with water or egg white; administer them.
¶ Modus Emplastri ad iuncturas, et ossa separata ex locis suis: et sedat dolorem accidentem eis, et scissuram ossis, et fracturam.	 Another emplastrum method for joints and separated bones from their places; it relieves pain that comes to them, and fissure of the bone, and fracture.
Sumatur lana succida, et submergatur in aceto, et oleo decocto: et ponatur super locum.	 Take sheared wool, immerse it in vinegar, boiled oil; place it on the location.
Et in hoc quidem Emplastro non est uirtus restaurationis, sed est bonum in sedatione apostematis calidi: et expellit dolores proprie.	 And in this emplastrum there is no virtue of healing, but it is good for the relief of hot boils; and it drives out pains properly.
¶ Modus Emplastri, quod restaurat os fractum.	 Method of Empalisting, which restores a broken bone.
Sume folia fici surdi, et folia papaueris syluestris: et tere omnia, et fac emplastrum ex utrisque.	 Take leaves from the fig tree of deafness and leaves from the wild papaver (opium poppy) tree; grind them all together and make an ointment from both.
¶ Modus Emplastri abbreuiati, administrati apud restaurationem fracturae ossis: et quando tu uis resolutionem residui apostematis.	 Method of quick emplasting for the restoration of a broken bone and when you wish to dissolve a remaining boil.
Recipe radicis alteae, et camomillae, et florum uiolarum, et farinae herbi, omnium ana partem unam: terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum uino, si non est membrum calefactum.	 Take equal parts of root of althea (marsh-mallow), chamomile, flowers of violets, and herb flour; grind all together and make a paste with wine if the member is not heated.
Si uero est calefactum, tunc confice illud cum aqua coriandri humidi, aut cum aqua, et utere eo.	 If it is heated (the affected area), then make the paste with warm coriander water or with water and use it.
¶ Modus Emplastri alius fortioris in resolutione, quam istud primum, quando accidit apostema durum apud restaurationem membri.	 Another stronger method for the dissolution (of a boil), which is more powerful than the first, when a hard boil appears during the restoration of a member.
Recipe radicis alteae, et seminis lini, et balaustiae, et melliloti, et samsuci, et floris uiolarum, et camomillae, omnium ana, partem unam, terantur omnia, et conficiantur cum aqua salicis, aut cum aqua dulci, aut cum uino.	 Take equal parts of root of althea (marsh-mallow), linseed, balustium (balm of Gilead), melilotus, samsucci (white poplar), flowers of violets and chamomile; grind all together and make a paste with sweet water, salix water or wine.
Totum illud secundum caliditatem membri, et quietem caloris eius.	 Apply this (paste) according to the warmth of the member and the calmness of its heat.
Hippocrates uero non dixit in libro suo, quod ponatur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius, nisi caerotum factum ex caera, et oleo: non aliud: et narrauit, ut sit medium inter grossitudinem et subtilitatem.	 Hippocrates, however, did not say in his book that it should be placed on a broken member during its restoration except for a plaster made from beeswax and oil; no other (substance); and he said that it should be medium between thickness and subtlety.
Galeno autem uisum est, ut ponantur super membrum fractum apud restaurationem eius res, in quibus est exiccatio caliditatis, sicut myrrha, et aloes et olibanum, et similia eis ex eis quae narrauimus.	 Galenus, however, saw fit that such materials should be placed on a broken member during its restoration as those in which there is an absorption of heat, such as myrrh, aloes and frankincense, and similar ones from what we have mentioned.
¶ Modus Emplastri quod confert ad laesionem et dolorem.	 Method of plaster application for wound and pain.
Recipe mugath, et ciceris, et capillorum hominis incisorum, aut pennae auis, et alteae, et salis partes aequales: terantur, et cribellentur, et conficiantur: et fiat ex eo emplastrum.	 Mix ground figs, chickpeas, human hair cuttings or bird feathers, alum and equal parts of salt. Grind and sieve them, then make a plaster from this mixture.
Quantitas autem secundum quam oportet, ut remaneat ligatura, deinde soluatur, est, ut consideres tunc, si non accidit infirmo dolor, neque pruritus, neque mouetur os fractum a loco suo: tunc non resoluas ipsum diebus multis.	 The amount that should remain bound depends on whether pain does not occur, nor itchiness, nor is the broken bone moved from its place. Then do not dissolve it for many days.
Quod si accidat ei in loco pruritus uehemens, aut dolor inquietans, aut inflatio: tunc propera, et solue in hora ipsum, et aufer emplastrum ab eo: et accipe pannum lenem, aut spongiam marinam lenem, humidam: et submerge eam in aqua tepida, et ablue cum ea locum, donec quiescat pruritus, et sedetur dolor.	 If there is severe itchiness, disturbing pain or swelling at the site, then hurry and dissolve it within an hour, remove the plaster from it: take a soft cloth or seawater-soaked sponge, moisten it with warm water, wash the area until the itchiness subsides and the pain is relieved.
Deinde dimitte membrum quiescere una hora.	 Then let the limb rest for one hour.
Deinde pone super ipsum lanam succidam, submersam in aceto et oleo, aut oleo rosato: et liga super ipsum nocte una, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido, et quiescat inflatio membri, et remoueatur dolor eius.	 Then place on it a piece of soft, vinegar- and oil-soaked wool or rose oil: tie it over it at night until you are safe from a hot abscess, the swelling of the limb subsides, and the pain is relieved.
Deinde itera ipsum ad stricturam subtilem, et emplastrum paruum: et non stringas ipsum constrictione tua prima, et subtilia cum eo, donec sanetur.	 Then repeatedly apply fine binding and small plaster: do not bind it with your initial tight binding or delicate bandages until it is healed.
Quod si uides, quod apostema, et rubedo, et dolor, et inflatio, et omnia accidentia iam remota sunt penitus, et indiges emplastro et strictura, tunc itera illud sicut fecisti in primis aequaliter.	 If you see that the abscess, redness, pain, swelling and all other symptoms have been completely removed, and if you need plaster and binding, then do as before equally.
Quod si non accidit membro aliquid ex eis quae diximus, tune non soluas ipsum, nisi post tres dies, aut quatuor, aut quinque, aut septem.	 If there is no symptom in the limb that we mentioned before, then do not dissolve it, unless after three days, four, five or seven.
Et quando que dimittitur uiginti diebus totum illud, secundum quod apparet tibi ex solutione membri, sicut diximus, donec quando adhaeret fractura, et approximat coagulatio carnis super eam: adde etiam tunc in strictura plus quam strictura tua prima tota: et adde etiam in ingrossatione cibi infirmi, secundum quod praecessit rememoratio eius.	 And when it is released after twenty days, according to your observation from the dissolution of the limb, as we said, until the fracture adheres and the coagulation of flesh grows on it: also add more binding in your binding than your first binding, and also increase the amount of weak food, according to the reminder of its presence.
Si autem uides locum fracturae iam exiccari, et extenuari plus quam oportet: tunc scias, quod nutrimentum prohibetur peruenire ad ipsum.	 If you see that the place of the fracture is already drying out and shrinking too much: then you know that nourishment is prevented from reaching it.
Embroca ergo ipsum cum aqua tepida apud omnem uicem qua soluis ipsum, et sit illud in omnibus tribus diebus, et alleuia stricturam parumper.	 Pour warm embrocation onto it at every juncture where you are dissolving it, and let it be for all three days, and alum tighten it slightly.
Per hanc ergo operationem currit ad membrum nutrimentum, et sanatur uelociter.	 By this procedure, nourishment flows to the limb and it heals quickly.
Illud autem quod faciunt stolidi restauratores ex fractura membri uice alia, quando non restauratur in primis, secundum quod oportet, et restauratur secundum tortuositatem, est error ex operatione eorum, et timor magnus: et si esset rectum, dixissent illud antiqui in libris suis, et operati fuissent cum eo.	 But what foolish restorers do, replacing the fracture of a limb by another method, when it should not be replaced at all according to what is necessary, and it is replaced crookedly, is an error from their procedure, and great fear: and if it had been correct, they would have said it in their ancient books, and operated with it.
Et ego non uidi alicubi eorum uestigium in illo omnino, et rectius est, ut non fiat illud.	 And I did not see any trace of theirs at all in that matter, and it is more correct to not do that.
¶ De factura accidente in capite.	 [Section] On the making of an injury in the head.
Caput III.	 Chapter III:
Species fracturae sunt diuersae, et figurae eius multae: et caussae eius sunt distinctae.	 Species of fractures are diverse, and their shapes numerous: and causes of it are distinguished.
Nam ex fractura est quae fit a percussione cum ense: et percussio aufert os totum usquequo peruenit ad siphac, quod est sub osse, sicut facit axia in ligno: et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Axialis.	 From a fracture is one that occurs from a blow with a sword, and the blow removes the bone completely to where it reaches the pith, which is under the bone, just as an ax does in wood; and because of this, this type of fracture is called Axial Fracture.
Aut ensis incidit quiddam ossis, et incidit faciem eius, et non penetrat incisio usque ad ultimum eius: et nominatur haec species fracturae Kalaan, id est, Leuatio absolute.	 Or a sword cuts something of the bone and cuts its face but does not cut through to the end of it; and this type of fracture is called Calcan, that is, Absolute Lever Fracture.
Et est uulnus duarum fracturarum, aut magnum, aut paruum.	 And there is a wound of two fractures, either large or small.
Et ex fractura est, quae est contritio, aut attritio: et caussa eius est percussio cum lapide, aut casus super lapidem, aut eis similia.	 And from a fracture is one that is crushing, or grinding; and the cause of it is a blow with a stone, or a fall upon a stone, or similar things.
Et haec fractura est etiam aut penetrans, quae iam appropinquat panniculo, quod est sub osse: aut est in facie ossis: et est uulnus harum duarum fracturarum etiam aut paruum, aut magnum.	 And this fracture is also penetrating, which already approaches the flesh that is under the bone; or it is on the face of the bone; and this type of fracture has a wound, either small or large.
Et ex fractura est, quae est occulta in osse in subtilitate capilli: et est fissura parua, et propter illud nominatur haec species fracturae Capillaris.	 And from a fracture is one that is hidden in the bone at its subtlety (the tip) of a hair; and it is a small crack, and because of this, this type of fracture is called Hairline Fracture.
Et ex eis est fractura, quae fit a casu, aut percussione lapidis, et eis similium, quae faciunt ingredi laminam ossis ad interiora, et fit loco concauitas: sicut accidit caldariis aeris, quando occurrit eis percussio, et ingreditur pars eorum ad interiora.	 And from these (fractures) is a fracture that occurs from a fall or blow of a stone and similar things, which make the layer of bone to enter inside and make a hollow place; as happens with brass caldrons when they are struck and part of them enters inside.
Et plurimum quidem fit illud in capitibus humidorum ossium, sicut sunt capita puerorum.	 Indeed, it most frequently occurs in the bones of moist heads, such as those of children's skulls.
Et fiunt omnibus istis speciebus fracturae satagiae separatae, et ego ueniam cum rememoratione illius totius in loco suo.	 And all these types of fractures are set separately, and I will return with a reminder of this (treatise) to its place.
Et cognoscimus omnes has species fracturae per detectionem super eam, et inquisitionem earum cum tentis, et ablationem carnium corruptarum, quae sunt super eas.	 We know all these types of fractures through examination upon them, and investigation of their nature with probing, and removal of the rotten flesh that is on them.
Species uero Capillaris cognoscitur per hoc, quod detegitur super os, et abstergitur, et linitur super ipsum cum encaustro: fractura enim apparet nigra.	 The species of Capillaris is known by this, that it appears on the face and is scraped off and sewn over with an ointment; for the fracture appears black.
In curatione autem fracturae, considera in primis accidentia infirmi: tunc si uides ex accidentibus quod significet significatione manifesta super timorem, sicut uomitus cholerae, et extensio, et amissio intellectus, et abscisio uocis, et syncopis, et febris acuta, et egressus oculorum, et rubedo eorum, et similia eis ex accidentibus in pluribus dispositionibus, proculdubio non sanatur: et si uides accidentia non terrentia te, et speras salutem: tunc incipe curationem eius.	 In the treatment of a fracture, consider first the condition of the patient; then if you see from his conditions that it indicates a manifest sign of fear, such as cholera vomiting, stretching, loss of intellect, absence of speech, fainting, acute fever, eye discharge, redness of eyes and similar conditions in multiple disorders, without a doubt it will not heal; but if you see non-terrifying conditions and hope for recovery, then begin the treatment.
Quod est, si uenit ad te uulneratus in primis cum uulneratur: et est illud in diebus hyemis, tunc oportet, ut studeas in ablatione ossis ante diem quartumdecimum secundum omnem dispositionem.	 If someone comes to you wounded first with a wound, and this is in winter days, then it is necessary that you strive for the removal of the bone before the 14th day under any circumstances.
Et si est in diebus aestatis, tunc oportet, ut properes remouere os ante diem septimum, antequam corrumpatur quod est sub osse ex panniculo, et accidant illa accidentia quae narrauimus.	 And if it is in summer days, then it is necessary to hurry and remove the bone before the 7th day, before what is under the bone from fat corrupts, and such conditions occur as we have mentioned.
Quod si fractura ossis iam peruenit ad panniculum tangentem cerebrum, et est cum minutiis, et attractione: tunc oportet, ut incidas partem comminutam, et attritam, secundum quod narro tibi.	 If the fracture of a bone has already reached the fat touching the brain and is accompanied by grinding and pulling, then it is necessary to cut the grinded and smoothed part, as I have told you.
Et est, ut radas caput uulnerati: et detege super os secundum quemcunque modum possibile est tibi: et secundum figuram uulneris, et quod leue est super infirmum.	 And it is necessary to shave the head of the wounded person; and to examine the face according to whatever method possible for you; and according to the shape of the wound, and what is light on the patient.
Quod si accidat tibi apud detectionem ossis fluxus sanguinis, aut apostema calidum: tunc oppone ei cum eo quod oportet.	 If blood flow or hot abscess occurs to you while examining the bone, then oppose it with what is necessary.
Et est, ut impleas locum cum pannis infusis in uino, et oleo rosato: et facias quiescere uulnus, donec sedetur apostema, et sis securus a fluxu sanguinis.	 And it is that you fill the place with cloths soaked in wine and rose oil; and make the wound rest until the abscess settles, and be careful of bleeding.
Deinde incipe in curatione ossis, et ablatione eius.	 Then begin with the treatment of the bone, and its removal.
Et illud fit secundum unum duorum modorum.	 And that is done according to one of two methods.
Modus quidem unus est, ut incidas os cum Incisorio strictae aciei: et haec est forma eius.	 One method is to cut the bone with a sharp knife; and this is its form.
Dende administra Incisorium aliud post Incisorum latius eo parumper: et haec est forma eius.	 Then administer another knife wider than the first, somewhat; and this is its form.
Deinde administra etiam Incisorium aliud latius etiam quam secundum.	 Then administer yet another knife even wider than the second one.
Et modus secundus est, ut sit apud te numerus Incisoriorum diuersorum: quorum quaedam sint latiora quibusdam, et quaedam eorum breuiora quibusdam: et sint in ultimo acuitatis extremitatum suarum, et sint ex ferro indo, aut fuled: et utere facilitate in percussione super Incisorium, ut non concutiat caput, et laedat ipsum.	 And the second method is that you have a number of different knives; some of which are wider than others; and some shorter than others; and they should be at the ends of sharpness, and made of iron or steel; and use them with ease in striking the knife, so as not to hit the head and hurt it.
Si autem os est forte, durum: tunc oportet, ut perfores in circumitu eius, antequam tu administres Incisoria, cum Terebris quae nominantur Terebra non profundantia: et non nominantur ita, nisi quoniam ipsa non pertranseunt terminum ossis carnei ad illud, quod est post ipsum: propterea, quod Terebro est extremitas rotunda super illud, quod est sub capite eius acuto, similis margini, et circulus paruus prohibet submergi, et pertransire spissitudinem ossis.	 If the bone is hard, then it is necessary to bore around its circumference before you administer the knife, with trephines that are not too deep; and they are not called thus unless because they do not penetrate through the bone to what lies beyond it; therefore the tip of the trephine is rounded above that which is beneath the head, sharp below, like an edge, and a small circle prevents submerging and penetrating the thickness of the bone.
Et conuenit tibi, ut accipias ex istis Terebris numerum multum, quorum unumquodque conueniat quantitati spissitudinis ossis, donec praesens sit tibi omni craneo Terebrum: cuius extremitatis acutae quantitas in longitudine et breuitate sit, secundum quantitatem spissitudinis illius cranei.	 And it is suitable for you to take a number of these trephines, one of which should correspond to the thickness of the bone, until the present bone has all the trephines; whose sharp edges should be of a quantity in length and width, according to the thickness of that skull.
Et haec est forma trium specierum Terebrorum, uel Trepanorum.	 And this is the form of three kinds of trephines or trepans.
Qualitas autem perforandi in circumitu ossis fracti, est: ut ponas Terebrum super os, et reuoluas ipsum digitis tuis, donec scias, os iam penetratum esse.	 The nature of the perforation on the bone fracture is as follows: you should place the trephine upon the bone and turn it with your fingers until you know that the bone has already been penetrated.
Deinde permuta Terebrum ad locum alium, et pone quod est inter omne foramen quantitatem grossitudinis radii, aut circiter illud.	 Then change the trephine to another place and place there the size of a fingertip within every hole, or about that much.
Deinde incide cum Incisoriis quod est inter omne foramen ex osse: et fac illud subtilius quam potes super illud ex fine leuitatis, sicut diximus, donec eradices os, aut manu tua, aut cum aliquo alio ex quibusdam instrumentis, quae parasti ad illud: sicut tenaliae, et forpices subtiles.	 Then cut with the chisels what is between each hole in the bone, and make that more delicate than possible on top of the edge of smoothness, as we said, until you root out the bone, either with your hand or with some other tools which you have prepared for it: such as tenaliae and subtle forpices.
Et oportet, ut caueas omni cautela, ne tangat Terebrum, aut Incisorium aliquid ex siphac.	 And it is necessary that you take all caution so that the trephine or chisel does not touch any part of the skull.
Cum ergo circumieris os perforando, et separatum fuerit a siphac, si fuerit continuum cum eo, et extraxeris ipsum, oportet ut radas, et aeques extremitatem eius quod remanet in osse cum instrumento alio simili Incisorio.	 When you are perforating the bone and it is separated from the skull, if it is continuous with it and you extract it, it is necessary that you file down, and even out the remaining part on the bone with another similar chisel.
Verumtamen oportet, ut sit tenuis et subtilis magis aliis Incisoriis.	 Nevertheless, it should be thin and delicate more than other chisels.
Quod si remanet aliquid ex ossibus paruis, et satagiae: tunc accipe ea cum facilitate, cum eo quod est apud te ex instrumentis.	 If some part of the small bones remains and the cartilages: then take them with ease, with whatever tools are at hand.
Deinde cura uulnus post illud cum liciniis, et unguentis quae diximus.	 Then care for the wound after that with linen and ointments as we said.
Et modus alius operationis est facilis, prorsus longinquus a timore: quem dixit Galenus, et laudauit ipsum laude magna: et iste est sermo eius.	 Another method of the operation is easy, completely far from fear: which Galen said and praised it greatly: this is his speech.
Necese est tibi in primis, ut incipias detegere partem ossis ex loco, in quo fractura est uehementior, et manifestior: donec quando detexeris illam partem, et posueris sub eo extremitatem huius Incisorii lenticularis, cuius haec est forma.	 It is necessary for you first to begin to remove the bone from the place where the fracture is more violent and clear: until when you have removed that part, and placed under it the end of this concave chisel, whose shape this is.
Et pars lenticularis, lenis non incidit aliquid: et pars acuta eius in duabus lateribus eius uadens in longitudinem, sicut uides: ut sit pars lenticularis innixa ad siphac, facie eius incidente acuta in osse.	 And the concave part of the lens, not cutting anything: and the sharp part of it extending in two sides of it, as you see: so that the concave part of the lens is attached to the siphoid, with its sharp edge incident on the bone.
Deinde percute super Incisorium a parte una cum malleo paruo, donec incidas totum os cum facilitate, sicut reuoluitur: et tu sis securus ex panniculo, quod non accidat in eo accidens, quod timeas prorsus.	 Then strike upon the Incisorium from one side with a small hammer, until you cut through the bone easily, as is customary: and be careful that no cloth happens to fall into it, which might happen accidentally, which you fear entirely.
Et si medicans non esset stultior hominum, et magis ignarus eius, nec esset dormiens, tunc si remaneret aliquid annexum ossi ex panniculo in quibusdam locis, incideret ipsum ab eo cum extremitate incisorii lenticularis ipsius, et liberaret ipsum ab eo cum facilitate.	 And if the physician were not more foolish than men, nor ignorant of it, nor asleep, then if anything remained attached to the bone from the cloth in some places, he would cut it off along with the edge of the incisorium lenticularis itself, and remove it easily.
Liberatur enim ab eo sine nocumento, et absque timore.	 It is freed from it without harm, and without fear.
Et si fractura ossis non penetret usque ad panniculum, et illud quod abscinditur ab osse est facies eius, et remanent in ipso asperitas et satagiae subtiles: tunc oportet, ut radas illam asperitatem, et eradices illas satagias cum rasoriis subtilibus ex quibus praeparasti numerum diuersarum quantitatum, ut sit tibi possibile administrare ex eis in omni loco conuenientiora eorum, et rectiora ipsorum, secundum illud ad quod perducit te operatio, et ipsum os fractum, et figura eius.	 If the bone fracture does not penetrate to the cloth, and that which is cut off from the bone is its face, and coarseness and subtle spicules remain in it: then it is necessary that you smooth out that roughness, and grind out those spicules with finer rasps, which you have prepared in various amounts, so that it is possible for you to apply them more conveniently and correctly at each place according to the operation, and the fractured bone, and its figure.
Et oportet, ut administres in rasione tua, qua in primis radis os, latius illorum rasoriorum.	 And it is necessary that you administer it according to your own measure, first grinding the bone more widely with those rasps.
Deinde utere post ipsum subtiliore eo.	 Then use a finer one after it.
Et non cesses facere illud secundum continuitatem, donec peruenias ad administrandum tenuius, et subtilius eorum omnium.	 And do not cease to do that continuously until you reach administering it more thinly and finer of them all.
In unaquaque autem fissurarum reliquarum paruarum capillarium, et fractura subtili, oportet ut administres curam, secundum illud quod perducit ad rectificationem eius.	 In each of the remaining small fissures and fine fractures, it is necessary to administer care according to that which leads to its correction.
Et est res quae non occultatur super omnem, cui in hac arte est quodlibet studium, et stetit super illud quod scripsimus, et ostendimus in fracturis magnis.	 And it is a matter that cannot be hidden over all, to which in this art every study applies, and it stands on what we have written and shown regarding large fractures.
Si autem panniculus detectus retinetur, quando tu eradicas os: tunc oportet, ut accipias pannum lini, secundum quantitatem uulneris, et submerge ipsum in oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super orificium uulneris.	 If the membrane is found to be retained when you are removing bone: then it is necessary that you take a linen cloth, according to the size of the wound, and immerse it in rose oil, and place it over the opening of the wound.
Deinde accipe pannum alium duplicatum, aut triplicatum, et submerge ipsum in uino et oleo rosa, et pone ipsum super pannum primum: et fac illud quam facilius potes super illud, ut non grauetur siphac.	 Then take another cloth, either doubled or tripled, and immerse it in wine and rose oil, and place it on top of the first one; make it as easy as possible to do so without burdening the wound.
Deinde administra supra ipsum ligamentum latum: et non stringas ipsum, nisi per quantitatem quae teneat uulnus tantum: et dimitte ipsum cum hac cura die uno, aut diebus duobus, donec sis securus ab apostemate calido.	 Then administer it on top of the broad ligament, and do not tie it unless for the amount that holds the wound only; and leave it with this care for one day or two days, until you are assured of being free from hot inflammation.
Deinde solue ipsum, et administra post illud medicinas cum quibus est superflua siccitas: sicut radices lilii, et farina herbi, et puluis thuris, et aristolochia, et similia eis: et est, ut facias ex istis medicinis puluerem, qui puluerizetur super uulnus sicut sunt siccae.	 Then dissolve it and administer the following remedies with which excessive dryness is needed: such as the root of the lily, and grain of wheat, and pepper, and aristolochia, and similar ones; and it is to be made from these remedies a powder that is powdered over the wound like dry things.
Et uniuersaliter administra in illo omnem medicinam de proprietate cuius est ut abstergat, et non mordicet.	 And universally administer all medicine with the property of purging and not biting (or harming).
Et caue secundum tuam uirtutem, ut uulnus in curatione tua sit limpidum: neque sit in ea sordes unguenti, neque sordicies.	 And be careful according to your strength (ability), so that the wound is clean during your treatment; neither let it be dirty with ointment nor filthy.
Neque dimittas uirus aggregari in eo omnino: quoniam quando uirus aggregatur super panniculum cerebri, corrumpit eum, et putrefacit ipsum, et accidit super infirmum post illud malicia magna: et iam accidit in siphac capitis, cum mundificatur ab eo os, praecipue quando negligitur cura eius, nigredo in superficie eius.	 Do not allow the pus to accumulate in it at all, since when pus collects on a cerebral membrane, it corrodes it and rots it, and afterwards a great evil happens after that; and this has already happened in the head wound, when the bone is being cleansed from it, especially when care of it is neglected, blackness appears on its surface.
Considera ergo tunc, si accidunt infirmo accidentia quae diximus, scias, quia est pernitiosum proculdubio.	 Consider then, if afflictions occur to the sick as we have said, know that it is certainly dangerous (or fatal).
Et si nigredo non accidit, nisi a medicina quae ponitur super ipsum, et est in uirtute illius medicinae, ut faciat illam nigredinem: tunc oportet, ut accipias ex melle partem unam, ex oleo rosato partes tres, et linias cum eis pannum.	 If the swelling does not occur, unless it is caused by the medicine placed upon him, and it is in the power of that medicine to cause the swelling: then it is necessary for you to take one part from honey and three parts from rose oil, and anoint with them a cloth.
Deinde pone ipsum super siphac: postea cura ipsum cum speciebus curationis quae conueniunt, donec sanetur.	 Then place him on a sow's bladder: afterwards, take care of him with medicinal substances that are appropriate, until he is cured.
¶ De restauratione Nasi quando frangitur.	 On the Restoration of the Nose when it is Broken.
Caput IIII.	 Chapter IV.
Scias, quod non franguntur ex Naso nisi duae partes eius superiores simul, aut una earum: propterea, quod ipse sunt duo ossa: quoniam inferius eius est cartilaginosum, non frangitur, et non accidit ei nisi attritio, et tortuositas, et simitas.	 Know that the nose is not broken except for its two superior parts together or one of them: this is because there are two bones in it; since its lower part is cartilaginous, it does not break and no other damage occurs to it except abrasion, twisting, and deviation.
Si frangitur una duarum partium eius, tunc oportet, ut intromittas digitum paruum in foramen Nasi, et aeques illam fracturam digito tuo indice, et pollice deforis, donec redeat Nasus super figuram suam naturalem: et fiat illud arte, cum facilitate.	 If one of the two parts is broken, then it is necessary for you to insert a small finger into the nostril and align the fracture with your index and thumb fingers from outside until the nose returns to its natural shape; and this should be done skillfully and easily.
Et caue, ne accidat per operationem tuam illam super infirmum dolor.	 And beware that during your procedure you do not cause pain to the sick person.
Quod si fractura est in superiore parte Nasi, et non perueniat ad illam digitus: tunc oportet, ut aequetur extremitate radii, in quo sit grossitudo parua.	 If the fracture is in the superior part of the nose and the finger does not reach it: then the radius must be aligned at the end where there is a small bulge.
Si uero fractura est in duabus partibus, tunc fac simile illius: et propera cum restauratione eius in die primo fracturae, si est possibile.	 If the fracture is in two parts, then do the same: and hasten with its restoration on the first day of the fracture, if possible.
Et si non, tunc post diem septimum, aut decimum apud quietem apostematis calidi.	 And if not, then after the seventh or tenth day in a warm room of sweating patients.
Deinde intromitte in extremitate Nasi licinium ex panno lini, si fractura est in parte una: aut intromite duo licinia si fractura est in duabus partibus: et sit in licinio grossitudo tantae quantitatis, quae impleat foramen Nasi.	 Then insert a strip of linen from a flax cloth into the end of the nose if the fracture is in one part; or insert two strips if the fracture is in two parts: and let there be a bulge of sufficient size on the linen to fill the nostril.
Et dixerunt quidam antiquorum restauratorum, ut infundantur licinia in butyro, et permutentur omni die.	And some of the ancient restorers said that linseed should be poured into butter and exchanged daily.
Illud uero non uidetur mihi, imo oportet, ut infundatur licinium in albugine oui, confecto cum puluere molendini.	 That does not seem right to me, on the contrary, it should be that linseed is poured into butter made from cow's milk, mixed with flour milled powder.
Deinde dimitte licinium, donec firmetur os, et induretur cartilago.	 Then let the linseed go until the bone hardens and the cartilage becomes calloused.
Et quandoque intromittitur in Nasum loco licinii penna anseris, postquam inuoluitur super ipsam pannus lenis: et fit, quod ipsa tenet fracturam Nasi uehementius, et ut non prohibeatur infirmus ab inspiratione.	 And sometimes a goose feather is inserted into the place of the linseed, after it has been covered with soft cloth; and this causes the fracture in the nose to be held more firmly, and prevents the weak from being prevented from breathing.
Et non est haec res necessaria.	 And this is not necessary.
Si uis, fac illud: et si uis, fac licinia.	 If you wish, do it; if you wish, do it with linseed.
Quod si accidat Naso iterum dum operaris apostema calidum, emplastra nasum cum caeroto, aut cum coto infuso in oleo rosato, aut modico ex dyaquilon.	 If the nose again occurs while you are operating on a boil, fill the nose with hot plasters made of alum or pitch soaked in rose oil or with a little jalap.
Si autem non accidit apostema calidum, tunc oportet, ut emplastres ipsum cum farina sisami, et puluere thuris confecti cum albugine oui.	 But if it does not occur that the boil is hot, then it is necessary to fill it with plasters made of wheat bran and incense powder mixed with butter from cow's milk.
Deinde pone super ipsum stuppam lenem, et non liges Nasum cum aliquo omnino.	 Then place a soft wad on top of it, and do not tie the nose with anything at all.
Si uero franguntur ossa Nasi fractura parua, aut comminuuntur, tunc oportet, ut scindas super ea, et extrahas ipsa cum instrumentis quae conueniunt eis.	 If the bones of the nose are broken in a small fracture or ground, then it is necessary to cut through them and extract them with instruments that are suitable for them.
Deinde sue scissuram, et cura ipsum cum eo quod incarnat, et consolidat ex emplastris conuenientibus ad illud, uel unguentis.	 Then take care of it with it until it heals and hardens with suitable plasters or ointments.
Quod si accidat inter Nasum uulnus, tunc oportet, ut cures ipsum cum liciniis: et administres cannulam de plumbo, donec sanetur.	 If a wound occurs between the nose, then it is necessary to treat it with linseed; and administer a lead tube until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Mandibulae inferioris, quando disrumpitur.	 Chapter on the restoration of the lower jaw when it breaks apart.
Caput V.	 Chapter V.
Quando disrumpitur Mandibula inferior, et fractura eius non est cum uulnere: conspice tunc si est fractura eius deforis tantum, et non frangitur in duo, et curuatur ad interiora: tunc cognitio eius est facilis.	 When the lower jaw is broken and the fracture is not accompanied by a wound: observe then if the fracture is only on the outside and it does not break into two, and bends towards the inside: then its recognition is easy.
Oportet ergo, si est fractura eius in parte dextra, ut intromittas digitum indicem sinistrae in os infirmi: similiter si fractura est in mandibula sinistra, tunc intromitte indicem manus dextrae: et impelle cum eo gibbositatem fracturae deintus cum facilitate ad exteriora cum manu tua altera ab interiori parte ossis decenter, et cum eo aequa ipsam.	 Therefore, if the fracture is on the right side of the jaw, you should insert your left index finger into the weakened bone: similarly, if the fracture is in the left jaw, then insert your right index finger: and press with it the swelling of the fracture towards the outside with ease using your other hand from the inner part of the bone properly, and push it equally.
Quod si fractura mandibulae iam separata est in duo, tunc oportet, ut administres extersionem a duabus partibus, secundum rectitudinem: donec possibilis sit aequatio eius.	 If the fracture of the jaw has already separated into two parts, then it is necessary to administer traction from both sides, according to rectitude: until a possible alignment can be achieved.
Si autem iam accidit in dentibus commotio, aut disruptio: tunc stringe illos de quibus speras quod remaneant cum filo auri, aut argenti, aut seta.	 If however movement or displacement of the teeth has already occurred, or if they are broken: then bind them with a thread of gold, silver, or silk.
Deinde pone super mandibulam fractam caerotum.	 Then place linen cloth over the broken jaw.
Deinde pone super ipsum pannum duplicatum, et pone super pannum astellam magnam decenter factam: aut frustum cutis soleae aequale, in longitudinem mandibulae.	 Then place over it a double cloth and place on top of the cloth a large cross made properly or an equal piece of leather soles in length of the jaw.
Deinde liga ipsum desuper, secundum quod praeparatur tibi ligatura eius, et conuenit ipsius applicatio, donec non destruitur: et praecipe infirmo, uti tranquillitate et quiete: et pone cibum eius sorbitiones lenes.	 Then bind it above as you prepare the binding for it and its application is suitable until it is not destroyed: and tell the patient to remain calm and at peace: and place mild soft food for him.
Si autem estimas, quod iam alteratur aliquid figurae aliquo modorum: tunc propera, et solue ipsum in die tertio.	 If you think that something has changed in shape by some means: then go quickly and dissolve it on the third day.
Deinde rectifica quod alteratum est ex eo, et emplastra ipsum ex puluere molendini, cum albugine oui, aut cum farina sisami, postquam tu abstuleris caerotum: et pone super emplastrum lanam lenem.	 Then correct what has changed from it, and apply a plaster made of milled flour with egg white or with wheat flour, after you have removed the linen cloth: and place soft wool over the plaster.
Dum ergo permanet annexum illud emplastrum super ipsum, et non alteratur ossis dispositio, dimitte ipsum, ne soluas, donec sanetur: aut stringe fracturam.	 While that adhering plaster remains on it, and the bone arrangement does not change, leave it undisturbed until it heals; or suture the fracture.
Multotiens enim stringitur haec fractura in tribus septimanis.	 This fracture is frequently sutured in three weeks.
Quod si interim accidat apostema calidum, tunc administra illud quod diximus multotiens in sedatione eius, donec remoueatur illud apostema.	 If a warm abscess should occur meanwhile, then administer what I said several times for its alleviation until the abscess is removed.
Et si fractura est cum uulnere, considera.	 And if there is a fracture with a wound, be aware.
Namsi iam separatur ex osse frustum, aut a satagie: tunc subtilia te in hoc, ut auferas illa frusta satagiae cum eo quod conuenit tibi in ablatione eorum ex instrumentis.	 If already the bone fragment is separating out, or from a wound bed: then be skillful in this matter, to remove those fragments of the wound bed together with what fits with you in their removal using instruments.
Si uero orificium uulneris est strictum, tunc amplifica ipsum cum phlebotomo secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae.	 If, however, the opening of the wound is narrow, then enlarge it with a leech according to your need.
Deinde quando abstuleris illa satagie, et non remanserit ex eis aliquid, sue tunc orificium uulneris, si est amplum: et si non, pone super ipsum ex emplastris quae conueniunt ad illud, et incarnant illud, donec sanetur.	 Then when you have removed the wound bed and nothing remains of it, or if the opening of the wound is wide: and if not, place on top of it ointments that are suitable for this, and let it heal until healed.
¶ De restauratione Furculae, quando frangitur.	 Chapter on Restoring a Fork (when it breaks).
Caput VI.	 Chapter VI.
Plurimum quidem frangitur Furcula ab anteriore parte ex parte humeri, et fractura eius fit secundum unum trium modorum.	 The fork breaks most often from the front part near the shoulder, and its fracture occurs according to one of three modes.
Aut enim frangitur et separatur in duo, praeter quod accidant in ea satagiae: et est facilius ad restaurationem eius.	 Or it breaks apart into two parts, apart from the presence of wound bed; and this is easier to restore.
Aut ita, quod accidunt in osse satagiae: et est difficilius ad restaurationem.	 "Likewise, that which happens in ossify satagia: and it is more difficult for restoration.
Aut ita, quod est fractura cum uulnere.	 "Likewise, that which is a fracture with a wound.
Et operatio in ea quando fractura est absque uulnere, est, ut facias praesentes esse duos ministros, ut teneat unus eorum adiutorium quod sequitur Furculam fractam, et alter extendat collum uersus partem.	 "And the operation in it when there is a fracture without a wound, is to have two assistants present, so that one holds the support for the broken furcula, and the other extends the neck towards the opposite side.
Deinde aequa fracturam digitis tuis, donec fiat forma eius, secundum quod oportet: et non sit in ea eminentia, neque concauitas.	 "Then make an equal fracture with your fingers until it takes the desired shape; there should be neither protrusion nor hollow in it.
Quod si indiges extensione plus, tunc oportet, ut ponas sub titillico infirmi spheram ex panno, aut lana: et sit magnitudo eius secundum quantitatem necessitatis tuae: et extende, et eleua Furculam, et coarta spheram manu tua, donec aeques fracturam, secundum quod oportet.	 "If you need more extension, then it is necessary to place a ball under the weak person's head made of cloth or wool; and let its size be according to your need; and stretch, lift, and compress the ball with your hand until an equal fracture is achieved, as required.
Quod si non potes trahere extremitatem Furculae ad exteriora: propterea, quia peruenit ad profundum: tunc oportet, ut resupinetur infirmus super ceruicem suam: et ponas sub humero eius puluinar medium in magnitudine, et premat minister humerum eius ad inferiora, donec eleuetur os Furculae quod est in profundo ad sursum: atque tunc rectifica fracturam, et aequa eam digitis tuis.	 "If you cannot pull out the extremity of the furcula because it has reached deep inside; then the weak person should lie on his neck; and place a puluinar medium under his shoulder in size, and press an assistant's shoulder towards the bottom, until the bone of the furcula that is deep inside is lifted upwards; and then correct the fracture and make it equal with your fingers.
Si autem sentis sathaiatum ex Furcula, et mouetur: tunc oportet, ut findas super illud, et extrahas ipsum alsathaiatum cum facilitate.	 "If you feel a swelling from the furcula and it moves; then you should press on it and extract the swelling with ease.
Si autem est retentum in osse, tunc ingenia in incisione eius cum uno Incisoriorum quae praeparasti ad illud, postquam tu posueris sub Furcula instrumentum quod seruat sifach: et est instrumentum ex ligno, aut ex ferro.	 "If it remains in the bone, then use your drill bit in its incision, after you have placed a saving instrument under the furcula; and the tool is made of wood or iron.
Et haec est forma eius.	 "And this is its form.
Assimilatur cochleari cui non est concauitas.	 "It resembles a spiral shell without hollow.
Et sit latitudo eius secundum illud quo indiges eo ex magnitudine ossis, et paruitate eius.	 "And let its width be according to the need for it from the size and part of the bone.
Longitudo uero eius etiam secundum quod possibile est tibi ad operationem.	 The length [of the instrument] is also as much as possible for you for the operation.
Et habeat duas extremitates, sicut uides: et extremitas una sit ampla, et altera stricta.	 It has two ends, as you see: and one end should be wide, and the other narrow.
Si autem disruptio uulneris quod scidisti quando extraxisti sathaiatum ossis, est ampla, et securaris ab apostemate calido: tunc aggrega duo labia uulneris cum sutura.	 If the wound opening that you cut when extracting the splinter of bone is wide, and it gapes, remove the hot cautery; then bring together two lips of the wound with stitches.
Et si disruptio est parua, aut times apostema calidum: tunc imple uulnus cum pannis, et puluillis secundum quantitatem scissurae uulneris.	 If the wound opening is small, or if you fear hot cautery; then fill the wound with cloths and lint according to the size of the wound incision.
Quod si accidat apostema calidum, tunc infunde pannum in oleo rosato, et aceto, et uino, et pone super ipsum.	 If hot cautery occurs, then soak the cloth in rose oil, vinegar and wine and place it on top of it.
Strictura uero ossis quando est absque uulnere, et absque sectione, est, ut ponas super os emplastrum factum ex farina molendini cum albugine oui.	 But the binding of the bone without a wound and without cutting is to place plaster made from milled flour with egg white on it.
Et pone stuppam lenem super ipsum.	 And place a soft woolen cloth over it.
Deinde pone spheram sub titillico eius, si indiges illa.	 Then place a sphere underneath if you need it.
Deinde accipe himematem, id est, rotam quam tenent Saraceni, quae sit longa ualde: et sit latitudo eius palmi unius, aut circiter illud.	 Then take the hemata, which is a roll that the Saracens hold, it should be very long; and its width should be one palm or approximately this much.
Deinde pone puluillum duplicatum super stuppam et emplastrum.	 Then place two lints on top of the woolen cloth and plaster.
Deinde accipe astellam ex tabula subtili, cuius latitudo sit trium digitorum, et in longitudine similiter.	 Then take a needle made from thin wood, whose width is three fingers, and similarly long.
Deinde inuolue eam in panno.	 Then thread the needle with the lint.
Deinde inuolue pannum illum cum astella in loco alhimemati qui cadit super fracturam et locum.	 Then sew the cloth at the place of the hemata that falls on the break and location.
Deinde pone alhimemati super fracturam sicut reuoluiur, et inuolue eam super collum eius, et sub titillico eius sano, et sub titillico eius infirmo: et reduc eam super omnem partem, et quomodo uides quod strictura tenet fracturam strictura decenti: et est illud, quod non occultatur super te, et totum, ut non remoueatur astella desuper os fractum.	 Then place the hemata on the break as they are rolled, and sew it over his neck, and under his healthy side, and under his weak side: and bring it over all parts, and so that the binding holds the break securely; and this is what will not be hidden from you, and entirely, so that the needle does not remove the broken bone.
Et propter hoc oportet, ut aspicias infirmum in omni die.	 It is necessary to examine the sick person every day.
Quotiens ergo mollificatur ligamentum, et uides astellam iam remoueri: tunc rectifica illud, et stringe ligamentum.	 Whenever the ligament becomes soft and you see the knot moving, then correct it, and tighten the ligament.
Deinde pone somnum infirmi super dorsum eius, et pone sub titillico eius apud somnum eius puluinar paruum in nocte, ut cum eo eleuetur adiutorium eius a latere ipsius.	 Then place the sick person's sleep on his back, and put a small awl under his sleep near his side, so that when he is raised up, help comes to him from his side.
Eleuatur ergo fractura furculae per eleuationem humeri.	 Raise then the fracture of the collarbone through the elevation of the shoulder.
Aut liga brachium eius ad collum ipsius: et non soluas ligamentum, si non accidat in loco accidens ex pruritu, aut ab apostemate, usque ad duodecim dies.	 Or bind his arm to his neck; and do not loosen the bandage unless it occurs at the place occurring from itch or abscess, until twelve days.
Deinde renoua emplastrum, si uideris faciem eius ad illud.	 Then renew the plaster if you see his face toward that (it).
Et adde in strictura, et dimitte ipsum, donec restauretur et coaguletur.	 And add to the incision, and let it be, until it is healed and coagulated.
Et fractura quidem furculae stringitur et confortatur secundum plurimum in uigintiocto diebus: et quandoque fit in quibusdam hominibus in minore illo.	 The fracture of the collarbone is tightened and supported for as many as forty days; and sometimes it happens to some people in less (time).
¶ De restauratione fracturae Spatulae.	 Chapter on the Restoration of a Fractured Spatula.
Caput VII.	 Chapter VII.
Raro frangitur Spatula, et in loco lato eius: et non franguntur ex ea nisi margines eius.	 A spatula rarely breaks, and when it does, it is usually at a wide place; and the edges are the only ones that break from it.
Quando ergo frangitur ex eo locus, et frangitur in medio eius, et non cognoscitur illud nisi per tactum: tunc secundum quod est figura fracturae conare praeparationem eius.	 When it breaks at that place, and breaks in the middle of it, and is not known unless by touch; then according to its shape, prepare the treatment for the fracture.
Et reduc eam super figuram naturalem omni modo ingenii, quod est tibi possibile.	 And bring it back to its natural shape in every way possible to you.
Deinde pone super locum puluerem molendini cum albugine oui, et stuppam lenem, et pone desuper puluillum ex panno duplato.	 Then put powder of millstone with egg white and soft wool on top, and place a small piece of double cloth on it.
Deinde pone super ipsum astellam latam ex tabula subtili secundum quantitatem Spatulae totius, aut ampliorem ea parum.	 Then put a wide knot made from thin wood of the same size as the spatula or slightly larger on top.
Si uero sub astella est concauitas in aliquo locorum Spatulae, tunc aequa illam concauitatem cum stuppa leni, donec descendat astella secundum aequalitatem.	 If there is a depression under a star in any spatula's handle, then equal the depression with soft wool until the star descends equally.
Deinde ftringe desuper cum alhimemati longa, constrictione decenti, et firmitudine astellae, donec non remoueatur a loco suo.	 Then roll over it with long alchemilla thread, using a suitable tightness and the firmness of the star, until it is not moved from its place.
Et considera ligamentum in omni die.	 And consider the suture in every day.
Quotienscunque ergo mollificatur ligamentum, stringe ipsum, et aequa astellam si remoueatur a loco suo: et iaceat infirmus super latus suum sanum.	 Whenever the suture is softened, tighten it and equalize the star if it moves from its place: let the weak lie on the side of the healthy.
Et Spatula quidem restauratur in uiginti diebus, aut in uigintiquinque diebus.	 And indeed the spatula is restored within twenty days or thirty days.
Quando ergo completur iste numerus, tunc solue ligamentum: et tu sis in securitate.	 When this number (20 or 30) is complete, then loosen the suture: and you will be safe.
Nam ipsa est ex ossibus quorum communitio non timetur, neque eorum solutio.	 For it is from bones whose fracture is not feared nor their solution.
Si autem procedat ex osse frustum, et pungit sub cute: tune scinde super ipsum, et aufer ipsum.	 If it proceeds from a bone fragment and pierces beneath the skin, then cut above it and remove it.
Et fac quod diximus in fractura furculae ex sedatione apostematis calidi, si accidat ex eo aliquid.	 And do as we have said in the fracture of a clavicle from the application of hot compresses if anything happens from it.
¶ De restauratione fracturae Pectoris.	 Chapter on the restoration of a breast fracture.
Caput VIII.	 Chapter 8.
Pectus quandoque frangitur in medio sui, et raro accidit illud.	 The breast is sometimes broken in the middle and it rarely happens.
Extremitates eius quidem plurimum franguntur, et comminuuntur ex accidentibus eius.	 Its extremities, however, are much more often broken and crushed due to their accidents.
Quando frangitur eius medium, quod declinat ad inferiora, et accidit ei dolor uehemens, et difficultas in anhelitu, et tussis: et fortasse euomit sanguinem, et declaratur concauitas in osse fracto, et non occultatur sensui, Restauratio eius est, ut resupinetur infirmus super dorsum suum: et pone inter Spatulas eius puluinar.	 When the middle of it is broken, which inclines towards the lower parts, and there occurs a violent pain, difficulty in breathing, and coughing; and perhaps blood vomiting occurs, and a depression is revealed in the fractured bone, and it is not hidden from sensation, its restoration is that the weak lies on its back: and place pulvinar between its spatulas.
Deinde preme humeros eius, et aggrega costas a duabus partibus uel lateribus cum manibus: et subtiliare in aequatione eius, secundum omnem modum quo possibile est illud et conuenit, donec redeat figura ossis, secundum quod oportet.	 Then press the humeri of it and join the ribs from both sides or flanks with hands: and compress in equal alignment of it, as much as possible for that and it agrees, until the shape of the bone returns, as it should be.
Deinde pone super ipsum emplastrum et stuppam, et pone desuper astellam ex tabula subtili ex salice, aut chalingi, et ex eis similibus in leuitate, postquam tu inuoluis eam in panno.	 Then place on top of it (the wound) an ointment and a stopper (bandage), and on top of that place a small wooden peg from subtle wood such as willow or boxwood, and similar ones in a thin form, after you have wrapped it in cloth.
Deinde subtiliare in ligando eam super os fractum, ut non remoueatur: et uade cum ligatura secundum rotunditatem ad dorsum aliquotiens, et stringe ipsum strictura decenti.	 Then bind it (the fracture) with a bandage so that it is not moved: and go around it according to its roundness to the back several times, and tighten it appropriately with a splint.
Deinde considera ligaturam in omni hora, et quotienscumque mollificatur, stringe eam: et si necessitas eius prouocat ad solutionem eius apud pruritum, uel corrosionem quae accidit in loco, aut dolorem, aut apostema: tunc propera, et solue eam, et eradica emplastrum, et rectifica quod accidit cum modo curationis eius.	 Then consider the bandage in every hour, and whenever it softens, tighten it: and if its loosening is caused by itching, corrosion that occurs at the place, or pain, or abscess: then hurry up, and unbind it, remove the ointment, and correct what has occurred with the method of its treatment.
Deinde reduc emplastrum, si uides ad illud faciem: et annecte ei stricturam, donec sanetur.	 Then apply the ointment back to the wound if you see it coming off: and attach a splint until it heals.
¶ De restauratione Costarum, quando franguntur.	 Chapter on the Restoration of Ribs when they are Broken.
Caput IX.	 Chapter IX.
Scias, quod Costarum fractura non accidit, nisi in locis grossis quae sequuntur dorsum, et ex extremitatibus earum ab anteriori parte.	 Know that the break of ribs does not occur except in large areas which follow the back and from their extremities on the front side.
Et non accidit eis attritio, nisi propterea, quia sunt cartilaginosae.	 And it does not happen to them because of rubbing, but rather because they are cartilaginous.
